thread.title: 'Fight man, fight:' Lamar Odom's friends are hoping for him to rebound
thread.title_full: 'Fight man, fight:' Lamar Odom's friends are hoping for him to rebound

author: courier-journal.com
title: 'Fight man, fight:' Lamar Odom's friends are hoping for him to rebound
text:
As Tuesday evening spilled into Wednesday morning and Lamar Odom's fate weighed on the minds of many, Daniel Artest was among the millions hoping for good news.
"I've been going around the house, and all I've been saying is, 'Fight man, fight. Just fight it. Fight, fight.' That's all," said the 32-year-old Daniel Artest, who met Odom as a 6-year-old growing up in New York through his older brother Ron Artest (now the Los Angeles Lakers' Metta World Peace). "I've been reading the news, and stuff like that online, and that whole situation, like how he was found and what not, but I don't care man. I don't care. I just want you to come home, man. Keep fighting. Just come home. We're here. We love you."
USA TODAY
Lamar Odom hospitalized after being found unresponsive in Nevada brothel
How did this all happen so fast, from Odom as a two-time champion, top-tier NBA talent and beloved teammate just four years ago to a post-Khloe Kardashian free fall that led him to a Nevada brothel where he was found unresponsive and rushed to a hospital where he remains Wednesday?
Even through all the negative headlines about DUIs and drug problems and the daily chronicling of his now-broken marriage with Kardashian, the reality television star, Odom inspired an affection that never waned. NBA players flooded Twitter with their support when the news of his condition first broke. According to a report from Mark Medina of the Los Angeles Daily News , several members of the Los Angeles Lakers, including friend and former teammate Kobe Bryant, visited him at Sunrise Hospital in Las Vegas after a preseason game against the Sacramento Kings that was played in Las Vegas.
AZCENTRAL
Reports: Khloé Kardashian flies to be with Lamar Odom
"Man, he's just real," said Daniel, who lives in New York with his family but is currently visiting his brother in Los Angeles. "Just that one word. He's real. It's always been real, always been love. Family, man. Always like a brother.
"I don't know what's been going on the past couple of years, but it just hurts so bad that he's going through that. It hurts so bad. I don't care what he's done, or whatever they say in the media…it's hard. He's like how much Ron means to me as a brother – he's up there. I don't have many people I can say that about, you know?"
Their shared New York roots are well-chronicled, as Odom was the Queens kid and Ron Artest the Queensbridge native who played together on AAU teams. Daniel would attend all their games, and over time he became part of their gritty group.
"I had the pleasure of playing against him at a basketball tournament in Queensbridge (N.Y.) a couple years back when I was in high school, and (their relationship) grew from there," he said. "He comes by the house, and it grew from there. At first, it was, 'Oh, that's Ron's friend,' and then it goes deeper than that."
But the part that Daniel can't reconcile is this image of Odom as a wandering soul. He ran into him not too long ago in Los Angeles, in fact, and said he hardly looked like a desperate man.
PHOTOS: LAMAR ODOM THROUGH THE YEARS
Los Angeles Clippers forward Lamar Odom against the Phoenix Suns at the US Airways Center. (Jan 2013) Mark J. Jason Merritt, Getty Images Fullscreen Los Angeles Lakers' Lamar Odom with his trophy as the winner of the 2010-2011 NBA Sixth Man Award, as the league's top reserve. (Apr 2011) Reed Saxon, AP Fullscreen Lakers Derek Fisher, Lamar Odom and Pau Gasol signal for a tie ball during a play against the Denver Nuggets at Staples Center. (Apr 2011) Robert Hanashiro, USA TODAY Sports Fullscreen Los Angeles Lakers power forward Lamar Odom drives to the basket guarded by Utah Jazz power forward Paul Millsap at the Staples Center. (Oct 2010) Robert Hanashiro, USA TODAY Sports Fullscreen Lamar Odom, Pau Gasol and Andrew Bynum celebrate the Lakers' 83-79 win over Boston in game 7 of the NBA Finals. (Jun 2010) Robert Hanashiro, USA TODAY Sports Fullscreen US Lamar Odom celebrates after winning a point during a World Cup Championship semi final basketball match US versus Lithuania in Istanbul. (Sep 2010) Aris Messinis, AFP/Getty Images Fullscreen From left, Kendall Jenner, Kim Kardashian, Kylie Jenner, Lamar Odom, Khloe Kardashian and Kourtney Kardashian at the Teen Choice Awards in Aug. 2010. Chris Pizzello, AP Fullscreen Lamar Odom and then-wife Khloe Kardashian arrive at the Philippe Restaurant West Hollywood grand opening in Oct. 2009. (Dec 1999) Robert Hanashiro, USA TODAY Sports Fullscreen Lamar Odom at 19 years old playing for the Redemption Christian Academy in Loudonville, NY. Tim Roske, AP Fullscreen Like this topic? You may also like these photo galleries: Replay Autoplay Show Thumbnails Show Captions Last Slide Next Slide "Whatever they're saying, you see him and it doesn't look like he's going through anything," Daniel said. "That's why I say I don't believe it (regarding the drug use), you know? I grew up in an area where when people would say stuff, like 'Somebody is doing this' or 'Somebody is doing that,' and I see it. Where I come from I can physically see it, and you know that this person is out of it. But that is not the case with this man. That's why it's so hard to believe."
Especially considering what he was told seven months ago. Despite the fact that Odom hadn't played in an NBA game since May 3, 2013, there were rumblings of another comeback that never came to pass. Daniel, a basketball talent in his own right who also labels himself "an aspiring personal trainer" on his Twitter page, had discussed the possibility of training Odom with his brother back in March.
"We talked about it once or twice," Daniel said. "I was all up for it, but it never came through."
But Odom was on his way even without Daniel's help, signing a two-year contract with the New York Knicks on April 16 (second year nonguaranteed) when his old mentor, team president and former Lakers coach Phil Jackson, decided to give him one last shot. Three months later, however, Odom was waived.
"Unfortunately, Lamar was unable to uphold the standards to return as an NBA player," Jackson said in a statement at the time. "We found it necessary to free up the roster spot."
It's all much bigger than basketball now, though. Lamar just needs to live.
"I just hope that God has mercy,'" Daniel said. "Just fight, man. Just fight."
